<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-deep-q-learning" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#deep-q-learning"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Deep Q-learning</h1>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-overview" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#overview"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Overview</h2>
<p dir="auto">Usually, we regard Deep Q Network as DQN, and it can also be called Reinforcement Learning (RL) whose aim is to achieve the desired behavior of an agent that learns from its mistakes and improves its performance.</p>
<p dir="auto">RL is a type of machine learning that allows us to create AI agents that learn from the environment by interacting with it to maximize its cumulative reward. Here is an image showing the basic RL operation principle:</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} 02_pipline
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/DQN/02_pipline.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/DQN/02_pipline.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">Pipline of DQN
:::</p>
<p dir="auto">From this image, we can see that at each step <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$k$</math-renderer>, the agent picks an action <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$u_k$</math-renderer>, receives an observation <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$y_k$</math-renderer> and receives a reward <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$r_k$</math-renderer>, and the environment receives an action <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$u_k$</math-renderer>, emits an observation <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$y_{k+1}$</math-renderer> and emits a reward <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$r_{k+1}$</math-renderer>. Later, the time increments k  k + 1. A one step time delay is assumed between executing the action and receiving the observation as well as reward. We assume that the resulting time interval <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$t = t_k  t_{k+1}$</math-renderer> is constant.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="Key characteristics of RL:
- No supervisor.
- Data-driven.
- Discrete time steps.
- Sequential data stream (not independent and identically distributed data).
- Agent actions affect subsequent data (sequential decision making)."><pre lang="{note}" class="notranslate"><code>Key characteristics of RL:
- No supervisor.
- Data-driven.
- Discrete time steps.
- Sequential data stream (not independent and identically distributed data).
- Agent actions affect subsequent data (sequential decision making).
</code></pre></div>
<h2 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-basic-terminology" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#basic-terminology"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Basic terminology</h2>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-reward" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#reward"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Reward</h3>
<p dir="auto">A reward is a scalar random variable <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$R_k$</math-renderer> with realizations <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$r_k$</math-renderer>:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Often it is considered a real-number <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$r_k \in \mathbb{R}$</math-renderer> or an integer <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$r_k \in \mathbb{Z}$</math-renderer>.</li>
<li>The reward function (interpreter) may be naturally given or is a design degree of freedom (i.e., can be manipulated).</li>
<li>It fully indicates how well an RL agent is doing at step <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$k$</math-renderer>.</li>
<li>The agents task is to maximize its reward over time.</li>
</ul>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="If we want the machine to flip a pancake:
- Pos. reward: catching the 180 rotated pancake
- Neg. reward: droping the pancake on the floor"><pre lang="{note}" class="notranslate"><code>If we want the machine to flip a pancake:
- Pos. reward: catching the 180 rotated pancake
- Neg. reward: droping the pancake on the floor
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">Rewards can have many different flavors and are highly dependent on the given problem:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Actions may have short and/or long term consequences.</li>
<li>The reward for a certain action may be delayed.</li>
<li>Examples: Stock trading, strategic board games,...</li>
<li>Rewards can be positive and negative real values.</li>
<li>Certain situations (e.g. car hits wall) might lead to a negative reward.</li>
<li>Exogenous impacts might introduce stochastic reward components.</li>
<li>Example: A wind gust pushes the helicopter into a tree.</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">Besides, the RL agents learning process is heavily linked with the reward distribution over time. Designing expedient rewards functions is therefore crucially important for successfully applying RL. And often there is no predefined way on how to design the best reward function.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-task-dependent-return-definitions" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#task-dependent-return-definitions"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Task-dependent return definitions</h3>
<h4 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-episodic-tasks" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#episodic-tasks"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Episodic tasks</h4>
<p dir="auto">Episodic tasks can naturally break into subsequences (finite horizon), for examples: most games, maze,... And the return becomes a finite sum: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$g_k = r_{k+1} + r_{k+2} + ... + r_{N}$</math-renderer>. Episodes end at their terminal step <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$k = N$</math-renderer>.</p>
<h4 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-continuing-tasks" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#continuing-tasks"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Continuing tasks</h4>
<p dir="auto">Continuing tasks lack a natural end (infinite horizon), for example: process control task, and the return should be discounted to prevent infinite numbers: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$g_k = r_{k+1} + \gamma r_{k+2} + \gamma^2 r_{k+3} + ... = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \gamma^{i} r_{k+i+1}$</math-renderer>. Here, <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$\gamma  {\mathbb{R}|0  \gamma  1}$</math-renderer> is the discount rate.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="From numeric viewpoint:
If $\gamma$ = 1 and $r_k$ &gt; 0 for $k  \infty $, $g_k$ gets infinite.
If $\gamma$ &lt; 1 and $r_k$ is bounded for $k  \infty$, $g_k$ is bounded.

From strategic viewpoint:
If $\gamma$  1: agent is farsighted.
If $\gamma$  0: agent is shortsighted (only interested in immediate reward)."><pre lang="{note}" class="notranslate"><code>From numeric viewpoint:
If $\gamma$ = 1 and $r_k$ &gt; 0 for $k  \infty $, $g_k$ gets infinite.
If $\gamma$ &lt; 1 and $r_k$ is bounded for $k  \infty$, $g_k$ is bounded.

From strategic viewpoint:
If $\gamma$  1: agent is farsighted.
If $\gamma$  0: agent is shortsighted (only interested in immediate reward).
</code></pre></div>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-state" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#state"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>State</h3>
<h4 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-environment-state" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#environment-state"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Environment state</h4>
<p dir="auto">Random variable <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$X_k^{e}$</math-renderer> with realizations <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$x_k^{e}$</math-renderer>:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Internal status representation of the environment, e.g.physical states (car velocity or motor current), game states (current chess board situation). financial states (stock market status).</li>
<li>Fully, limited or not at all visible by the agent:sometimes even foggy or uncertain, but in general: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$Y_k = f(X_k)$</math-renderer> as the measurable outputs of the environment.</li>
<li>Continuous or discrete quantity.</li>
</ul>
<h4 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-agent-state" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#agent-state"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Agent state</h4>
<p dir="auto">Random variable <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$X_k^{a}$</math-renderer> with realizations <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$x_k^{a}$</math-renderer>:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Internal status representation of the agent.</li>
<li>In general: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$x_k^{a} \neq x_k^{e}$</math-renderer>, e.g., due to measurement noise or an additional agents memory.</li>
<li>Agents condensed information relevant for next action.</li>
<li>Dependent on internal knowledge / policy representation of the agent.</li>
<li>Continuous or discrete quantity.</li>
</ul>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-action" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#action"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Action</h3>
<p dir="auto">An action is the agents degree of freedom in order to maximize its reward. The major distinctions are:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Finite action set (FAS): <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$u_k  {u_{k,1},u_{k,2}, ...}  \mathbb{R}_m$</math-renderer>.</li>
<li>Continuous action set (CAS): Infinite number of actions: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$u_k  \mathbb{R}_m$</math-renderer>.</li>
<li>Deterministic <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$u_k$</math-renderer> or random Uk variable.</li>
<li>Often state-dependent and potentially constrained: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$u_k  U(x_k)  \mathbb{R}_m$</math-renderer>.</li>
</ul>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="Evaluating the state and action spaces (e.g., finite vs. continuous) of a new RL problem should be always the first steps in order to choose appropriate solution algorithms."><pre lang="{note}" class="notranslate"><code>Evaluating the state and action spaces (e.g., finite vs. continuous) of a new RL problem should be always the first steps in order to choose appropriate solution algorithms.
</code></pre></div>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-policy" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#policy"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Policy</h3>
<p dir="auto">A policy <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$\pi$</math-renderer> is the agents internal strategy on picking actions.</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Deterministic policies: maps state and action directly: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$u_k = \pi (x_k)$</math-renderer>.</li>
<li>Stochastic policies: maps a probability of the action given a state: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$\pi(U_k|X_k) = \mathbb{P} [Uk|Xk]$</math-renderer> .</li>
<li>RL is all about changing <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$\pi$</math-renderer> over time in order to maximize the expected return.</li>
</ul>
<h4 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-example" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#example"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Example</h4>
<p dir="auto">Here is a deterministic policy example: find optimal gains <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">${K_p, K_i, K_d}$</math-renderer> given the reward <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$r_k = e^2_k$</math-renderer></p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Agents behavior is explicitly determined by <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">${K_p, K_i, K_d}$</math-renderer>.</li>
<li>Reference value is part of the environment state: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$x_k =[y_k y^_k]^T$</math-renderer>.</li>
<li>Control output is the agents action: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$u_k = \pi(x_k|K_p, K_i, K_d)$</math-renderer>.</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} 03_policy_example
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/DQN/03_policy_example.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/DQN/03_policy_example.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">Classical PID control loop with scalar quantities
:::</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-value-functions" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#value-functions"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Value functions</h3>
<p dir="auto">The state-value function is the expected return being in state <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$x_k$</math-renderer> following a policy <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$\pi:v_{\pi}(x_k)$</math-renderer>.</p>
<p dir="auto">Assuming an MDP problem structure the state-value function is $v_{\pi}(x_k) = \mathbb{E}<em>{\pi} [G_k | X_k = x_k] = \mathbb{E}</em>{\pi}[\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} \gamma^i R_{k+i+1} | x_k]$.</p>
<p dir="auto">The action-value function is the expected return being in state <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$x_k$</math-renderer> taken an action <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$u_k$</math-renderer> and, thereafter, following a policy <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$\pi: q_{\pi}(x_k,u_k)$</math-renderer>.</p>
<p dir="auto">Assuming an MDP problem structure the action-value function is $q_{\pi}(x_k, u_k) = \mathbb{E}<em>{\pi} [G_k | X_k=x_k, U_k=u_k] = \mathbb{E}</em>{\pi} [\sum_{i=0}^{\infty} \gamma^i R_{k+i+1} | x_k,u_k]$.</p>
<p dir="auto">A key task in RL is to estimate <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$v_{\pi}(x_k)$</math-renderer> and <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$q_{\pi}(x_k,u_k)$</math-renderer> based on sampled data.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-model" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#model"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Model</h3>
<p dir="auto">A model predicts what will happen inside an environment.</p>
<p dir="auto">That could be a state model <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$\mathcal{P}$</math-renderer>: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$\mathcal{P} = \mathbb{P}[X_{k+1}=x_{k+1}|X_k=x_k, U_k=u_k]$</math-renderer>. Or a reward model <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$\mathcal{R}$</math-renderer>: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$\mathcal{R} = \mathbb{P}[R_{k+1}=r_{k+1}|X_k=x_k, U_k=u_k]$</math-renderer>. In general, those models could be stochastic (as denoted above) but in some problems relax to a deterministic form. Using data in order to fit a model is a learning problem of its own and often called system identification.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-exploration-and-exploitation" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#exploration-and-exploitation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Exploration and exploitation</h3>
<p dir="auto">In RL the environment is initially unknown. How to act optimal?</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Exploration: find out more about the environment.</li>
<li>Exploitation: maximize current reward using limited information.</li>
</ul>

</code></pre></div>
<h2 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-main-algorithms" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#main-algorithms"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Main algorithms</h2>
<p dir="auto">In this section, we will take maze as an example. The problem statement is:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Reward: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$r_k = 1$</math-renderer>.</li>
<li>At goal: episode termination.</li>
<li>Actions: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="40f29d2ae72549015edcd45cc2c7eb87">$u_k \in {N, E, S, W}$</math-renderer>.</li>
<li>State: agents location.</li>
<li>Deterministic problem (no stochastic influences).</li>
</ul>

<h2 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-code" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#code"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Code</h2>
<p dir="auto">This is an example of DQN discrete model.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import tensorflow as tf
import maze
import maze_collection as mc
import random as r
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>import tensorflow as tf
import maze
import maze_collection as mc
import random as r
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
</code></pre></div>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="def main(output_file_name):
    # housekeeping
    m = maze.Maze(mc.T_maze)
    sess = tf.Session()
    learning_rate = 0.0001
    num_memory_units = 4
    graphical = True
    file_output = True

    if file_output is True:
        # output to file (this is set to overwrite!)
        file = open(output_file_name + &quot;.txt&quot;, &quot;w&quot;)
        file.write(&quot;Iter\tWon?\tSteps\tAll steps\n&quot;)

    # neural network structure
    x = tf.placeholder(tf.float32, [None, 2+num_memory_units])

    W1 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([2+num_memory_units, 6]))
    b1 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([1, 6]))

    h1 = tf.sigmoid(tf.matmul(x, W1) + b1)

    W2 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([6, 6]))
    b2 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([1, 6]))

    h2 = tf.sigmoid(tf.matmul(h1, W2) + b2)

    W3 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([6, 4+num_memory_units]))
    b3 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([1, 4+num_memory_units]))

    output_final_layer_before_activation_function = tf.matmul(h2, W3) + b3
    left_output = output_final_layer_before_activation_function[:, 0:4]
    right_output = output_final_layer_before_activation_function[:, 4:]
    y = tf.nn.softmax(left_output)
    memory_units = tf.sigmoid(right_output)

    sess.run(tf.global_variables_initializer())

    weights_list = [W1, b1, W2, b2, W3, b3]

    # gradients (i.e. dp/dw) for backpropagation
    dprobability0_dweights = tf.gradients(y[:, 0], weights_list)
    dprobability1_dweights = tf.gradients(y[:, 1], weights_list)
    dprobability2_dweights = tf.gradients(y[:, 2], weights_list)
    dprobability3_dweights = tf.gradients(y[:, 3], weights_list)

    # weight update operation
    ph_delta_weights_list = [tf.placeholder(tf.float32, w.get_shape()) for w in weights_list]
    update_weights = [tf.assign(weights_list[i], weights_list[i] + ph_delta_weights_list[i])
                      for i in range(len(weights_list))]

    # training setup
    maxSteps = 20
    iteration = 0
    maxIterations = 10000

    steps_taken = np.zeros(maxIterations)

    # Plot display -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    if graphical is True:
        spread = 50

        plt.ion()
        fig = plt.figure(&quot;Maze solver&quot;)
        ax = fig.add_subplot(111)
        ax.axis([0, maxIterations/spread + 1, 0, maxSteps + 1])
        plt.ylabel(&quot;Steps taken&quot;)
        plt.xlabel(&quot;Iterations ({})&quot;.format(spread))
        ax.plot([0], [0])
        ax.grid()

        iterations = []
        duration_history = []

    # Looping through iterations
    while iteration &lt; maxIterations:
        # Current step
        step = 0

        # All outputs and dp_dthetas for this iteration
        probabilities = np.zeros(maxSteps)
        dp_dthetas = list()

        memory = np.zeros(num_memory_units)

        movements = &quot;&quot;

        while m.won is False and step &lt; maxSteps:
            # Defining neural network input
            input_values = np.array([m.normal_x(), m.normal_y()])
            input_values = np.append(input_values, memory)

            # Running input through the neural network
            [output, dp0dtheta, dp1dtheta, dp2dtheta, dp3dtheta, output_memory] =\
                sess.run([y, dprobability0_dweights, dprobability1_dweights, dprobability2_dweights,
                          dprobability3_dweights, memory_units],
                         feed_dict={x: [input_values]})

            # Random value between 0 and 1, inclusive on both sides
            result = r.uniform(0, 1)

            if result &lt;= output[0][0]:
                # Up
                m.move_up()
                probabilities[step] = output[0][0]
                dp_dthetas.append(dp0dtheta)
                movements += &quot;U&quot;
            elif result &lt;= output[0][0] + output[0][1]:
                # Right
                m.move_right()
                probabilities[step] = output[0][1]
                dp_dthetas.append(dp1dtheta)
                movements += &quot;R&quot;
            elif result &lt;= output[0][0] + output[0][1] + output[0][2]:
                # Down
                m.move_down()
                probabilities[step] = output[0][2]
                dp_dthetas.append(dp2dtheta)
                movements += &quot;D&quot;
            elif result &lt;= output[0][0] + output[0][1] + output[0][2] + output[0][3]:
                # Left
                m.move_left()
                probabilities[step] = output[0][3]
                dp_dthetas.append(dp3dtheta)
                movements += &quot;L&quot;

            memory = output_memory[0]
            step += 1

        print(&quot;Iteration #{:05d}\tWon: {}\tSteps taken: {:04d}\tSteps: {}&quot;.format(iteration, m.won,
                                                                                  step, movements))
        if file_output is True:
            file.write(&quot;{:05d}\t{}\t{:04d}\t{}\n&quot;.format(iteration, m.won, step, movements))

        # Assigning a reward
        reward = maxSteps - (2 * step)  # linear reward function
        #reward = maxSteps - pow(step, 2)  # power reward function

        # Applying weight change for every step taken, based on the reward given at the end
        for i in range(step):
            deltaTheta = [(learning_rate * (1 / probabilities[i]) * reward) * dp_dthetas[i][j]
                          for j in range(len(weights_list))]

            sess.run(update_weights, feed_dict=dict(zip(ph_delta_weights_list, deltaTheta)))

        steps_taken[iteration] = step
        if graphical is True and iteration % spread == 0:
            steps_mean = np.mean(steps_taken[iteration-spread:iteration+1])
            iterations = iterations+[iteration/spread]
            duration_history = duration_history+[steps_mean]
            del ax.lines[0]
            ax.plot(iterations, duration_history, 'b-', label='Traj1')
            plt.draw()
            plt.pause(0.001)

        m.reset()

        iteration += 1
    if file_output is True:
        file.close()
    if graphical is True:
        if file_output is True:
            plt.savefig(output_file_name + &quot;.png&quot;)
        else:
            plt.show()
        #input(&quot;Press [enter] to continue.&quot;)
        plt.close()
    sess.close()"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>def main(output_file_name):
    # housekeeping
    m = maze.Maze(mc.T_maze)
    sess = tf.Session()

        # output to file (this is set to overwrite!)
        file = open(output_file_name + ".txt", "w")
        file.write("Iter\tWon?\tSteps\tAll steps\n")

    # neural network structure
    x = tf.placeholder(tf.float32, [None, 2+num_memory_units])

    W1 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([2+num_memory_units, 6]))
    b1 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([1, 6]))

    h1 = tf.sigmoid(tf.matmul(x, W1) + b1)

    W2 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([6, 6]))
    b2 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([1, 6]))

    h2 = tf.sigmoid(tf.matmul(h1, W2) + b2)

    W3 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([6, 4+num_memory_units]))
    b3 = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([1, 4+num_memory_units]))

    output_final_layer_before_activation_function = tf.matmul(h2, W3) + b3
    left_output = output_final_layer_before_activation_function[:, 0:4]
    right_output = output_final_layer_before_activation_function[:, 4:]
    y = tf.nn.softmax(left_output)
    memory_units = tf.sigmoid(right_output)

    sess.run(tf.global_variables_initializer())

    weights_list = [W1, b1, W2, b2, W3, b3]

    # gradients (i.e. dp/dw) for backpropagation
    dprobability0_dweights = tf.gradients(y[:, 0], weights_list)
    dprobability1_dweights = tf.gradients(y[:, 1], weights_list)
    dprobability2_dweights = tf.gradients(y[:, 2], weights_list)
    dprobability3_dweights = tf.gradients(y[:, 3], weights_list)

    # weight update operation
    ph_delta_weights_list = [tf.placeholder(tf.float32, w.get_shape()) for w in weights_list]
    update_weights = [tf.assign(weights_list[i], weights_list[i] + ph_delta_weights_list[i])
                      for i in range(len(weights_list))]

    # training setup
    maxSteps = 20
    iteration = 0
    maxIterations = 10000

    steps_taken = np.zeros(maxIterations)

    # Plot display -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    if graphical is True:
        spread = 50

        plt.ion()
        fig = plt.figure("Maze solver")
        ax = fig.add_subplot(111)
        ax.axis([0, maxIterations/spread + 1, 0, maxSteps + 1])
        plt.ylabel("Steps taken")
        plt.xlabel("Iterations ({})".format(spread))
        ax.plot([0], [0])
        ax.grid()

        iterations = []
        duration_history = []

    # Looping through iterations
    while iteration &lt; maxIterations:
        # Current step
        step = 0

        # All outputs and dp_dthetas for this iteration
        probabilities = np.zeros(maxSteps)
        dp_dthetas = list()

        memory = np.zeros(num_memory_units)

        movements = ""

        while m.won is False and step &lt; maxSteps:
            # Defining neural network input
            input_values = np.array([m.normal_x(), m.normal_y()])

            # Running input through the neural network
            [output, dp0dtheta, dp1dtheta, dp2dtheta, dp3dtheta, output_memory] =\

                probabilities[step] = output[0][3]
                dp_dthetas.append(dp3dtheta)
                movements += "L"

            memory = output_memory[0]
            step += 1

        print("Iteration #{:05d}\tWon: {}\tSteps taken: {:04d}\tSteps: {}".format(iteration, m.won,
                                                                                  step, movements))
        if file_output is True:
            file.write("{:05d}\t{}\t{:04d}\t{}\n".format(iteration, m.won, step, movements))

        # Assigning a reward
        reward = maxSteps - (2 * step)  # linear reward function
        #reward = maxSteps - pow(step, 2)  # power reward function

        # Applying weight change for every step taken, based on the reward given at the end
        for i in range(step):
            deltaTheta = [(learning_rate * (1 / probabilities[i]) * reward) * dp_dthetas[i][j]
                          for j in range(len(weights_list))]

            sess.run(update_weights, feed_dict=dict(zip(ph_delta_weights_list, deltaTheta)))

        steps_taken[iteration] = step
        if graphical is True and iteration % spread == 0:
            steps_mean = np.mean(steps_taken[iteration-spread:iteration+1])
            iterations = iterations+[iteration/spread]
            duration_history = duration_history+[steps_mean]
            del ax.lines[0]
            ax.plot(iterations, duration_history, 'b-', label='Traj1')
            plt.draw()
            plt.pause(0.001)

        m.reset()

        iteration += 1
    if file_output is True:
        file.close()
    if graphical is True:
        if file_output is True:
            plt.savefig(output_file_name + ".png")
        else:
            plt.show()
        #input("Press [enter] to continue.")
        plt.close()
    sess.close()
</code></pre></div>

<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-generative-adversarial-networks" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#generative-adversarial-networks"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Generative adversarial networks</h1>
<p dir="auto">The original purpose of Generative adversarial networks(GAN) is to generate new data. It classically generates new images, but is applicable to wide range of domains. It learns the training set distribution and can generate new images that have never been seen before. In contrast to e.g., autoregressive models or RNNs (generating one word at a time), GANs generate the whole output all at once.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="GAN is proposed in 2005, the paper is Ian J. Goodfellow, Jean Pouget-Abadie, Mehdi Mirza, Bing Xu, David Warde-Farley, Sherjil Ozair, Aaron Courville, Yoshua Bengio. &quot;Generative Adversarial Networks&quot;, arxiv:1406.2661."><pre lang="{seealso}" class="notranslate"><code>GAN is proposed in 2005, the paper is Ian J. Goodfellow, Jean Pouget-Abadie, Mehdi Mirza, Bing Xu, David Warde-Farley, Sherjil Ozair, Aaron Courville, Yoshua Bengio. "Generative Adversarial Networks", arxiv:1406.2661.
</code></pre></div>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-overview" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#overview"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Overview</h2>
<p dir="auto">The structures of GANs are roughly as follows. They have two essential part, discriminator and generator.
Discriminator learns to become better at distinguishing real from generated images, and generator learns to generate better images to fool the discriminator.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} GAN structure
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/GAN/structure.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/GAN/structure.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">Illustration of GAN structure
:::</p>
<p dir="auto">Then, one question appears: why are GANs Called Generative Models?</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>The generative part comes from the fact that the model "generates" new data,</li>
<li>Most of the time, generative models use an approximation to compute the usually intractable distribution; here, the discriminator part does that approximation,</li>
<li>So, it does learn p(x).</li>
</ul>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-training" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#training"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Training</h2>
<p dir="auto">To make the model converge, we need to find a proper objective for it.
For the GAN, it is $\min\limits_{G} \max\limits_{D} V(D, G) = \mathbb{E}<em>{x \thicksim p</em>{data}}[log D(x)] + \mathbb{E}_{z\thicksim p_z(z)}[log(1-D(G(z)))]$</p>
<h3 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-discriminator-gradient-for-update-gradient-ascent" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#discriminator-gradient-for-update-gradient-ascent"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Discriminator gradient for update (gradient ascent)</h3>
<p dir="auto">The aim of Discriminator is <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="a896430da81f5d9a48cfb9d050e47d44">$\bigtriangledown_{W_D} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n [log D(x^{(i)}) + log (1-D(G(z^{(i)})))]$</math-renderer>. We can split it into two parts.
First is <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="a896430da81f5d9a48cfb9d050e47d44">$D(x^{(i)})$</math-renderer>. If it predicts well in real images, the probability will be close to <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="a896430da81f5d9a48cfb9d050e47d44">$1$</math-renderer>.
Second is <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="a896430da81f5d9a48cfb9d050e47d44">$D(G(z^{(i)}))$</math-renderer>. This part use to predict the fake images which generdated from the generator, and if it predicts well, the probability will be close to <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="a896430da81f5d9a48cfb9d050e47d44">$0$</math-renderer>.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-generator-gradient-for-update-gradient-descent" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#generator-gradient-for-update-gradient-descent"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Generator gradient for update (gradient descent)</h3>
<p dir="auto">The aim of Generator is <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="a896430da81f5d9a48cfb9d050e47d44">$\bigtriangledown_{W_G} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n log(1-D(G(z^{(i)})))$</math-renderer>.
<math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="a896430da81f5d9a48cfb9d050e47d44">$D(G(z^{(i)}))$</math-renderer> is also used to predict fake images, but if it predicts badly on fake images, the probability will be close to 1, which is not same to discriminator.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-train-for-convergence" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#train-for-convergence"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Train for convergence</h3>
<p dir="auto">GAN converges when probabilities are close to 0.5, which means G can cheat D.
rom a mathematical point of view, it converges when Nash-equilibrium (Game Theory concept) is reached in the minmax (zero-sum) game.
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium" rel="nofollow">Nash-Equilibrium</a> in Game Theory is reached when the actions of one player won't change depending on the opponent's actions.</p>
<p dir="auto">But not each time GAN can converge, there are some training problems:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Oscillation between generator and discriminator loss,</li>
<li>Mode collapse (generator produces examples of a particular kind only),</li>
<li>Discriminator is too strong, such that the gradient for the generator vanishes and the generator can't keep up,</li>
<li>Discriminator is too weak, and the generator produces non-realistic images that fool it too easily (rare problem, though).</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">For the third problem, replacing <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="a896430da81f5d9a48cfb9d050e47d44">$\bigtriangledown_{W_G} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n log(1-D(G(z^{(i)})))$</math-renderer> with <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="a896430da81f5d9a48cfb9d050e47d44">$\bigtriangledown_{W_G} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n log(D(G(z^{(i)})))$</math-renderer> can be a good choice.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-loss" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#loss"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Loss</h3>
<p dir="auto">Discriminator:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Maximize prediction probability of classifying real as real and fake as fake,</li>
<li>Remember maximizing log likelihood is the same as minimizing negative log likelihood (i.e., minimizing cross-entropy).
Generator:</li>
<li>Minimize likelihood of the discriminator to make correct predictions (predict fake as fake; real as real), which can be achieved by maximizing the cross-entropy,</li>
<li>This doesn't work well in practice though because of gradient issues (zero gradient if the discriminator makes correct predictions, which is not what we want for the generator),</li>
<li>Better: flip labels and minimize cross entropy (force the discriminator to output high probability for fake if an image is real, and high probability for real if an image is fake).</li>
</ul>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-code" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#code"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Code</h3>
<p dir="auto">Here we implement a GAN model.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from IPython import display

from torch.utils.data import DataLoader
from torchvision import transforms, datasets

from utils import Logger

import tensorflow as tf
import tensorflow.compat.v1 as tf
tf.disable_v2_behavior() 

import numpy as np
from tensorflow.examples.tutorials.mnist import input_data

mnist=input_data.read_data_sets('./tf_data/VGAN/MNIST',one_hot=True)
DATA_FOLDER = './tf_data/VGAN/MNIST'
IMAGE_PIXELS = 28*28
NOISE_SIZE = 100
BATCH_SIZE = 100

def noise(n_rows, n_cols):
    return np.random.normal(size=(n_rows, n_cols))

def xavier_init(size):
    in_dim = size[0] if len(size) == 1 else size[1]
    stddev = 1. / np.sqrt(float(in_dim))
    return tf.random_uniform(shape=size, minval=-stddev, maxval=stddev)

def images_to_vectors(images):
    return images.reshape(images.shape[0], 784)

def vectors_to_images(vectors):
    return vectors.reshape(vectors.shape[0], 28, 28, 1)"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>from IPython import display

from torch.utils.data import DataLoader
from torchvision import transforms, datasets

from utils import Logger

import tensorflow as tf
import tensorflow.compat.v1 as tf
tf.disable_v2_behavior() 

import numpy as np
from tensorflow.examples.tutorials.mnist import input_data

mnist=input_data.read_data_sets('./tf_data/VGAN/MNIST',one_hot=True)
DATA_FOLDER = './tf_data/VGAN/MNIST'
IMAGE_PIXELS = 28*28
NOISE_SIZE = 100
BATCH_SIZE = 100

def noise(n_rows, n_cols):
    return np.random.normal(size=(n_rows, n_cols))

def xavier_init(size):
    in_dim = size[0] if len(size) == 1 else size[1]
    stddev = 1. / np.sqrt(float(in_dim))
    return tf.random_uniform(shape=size, minval=-stddev, maxval=stddev)

def images_to_vectors(images):
    return images.reshape(images.shape[0], 784)

def vectors_to_images(vectors):
    return vectors.reshape(vectors.shape[0], 28, 28, 1)
</code></pre></div>

<p dir="auto">Initialize Graph</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="## Discriminator

# Input
X = tf.placeholder(tf.float32, shape=(None, IMAGE_PIXELS))

# Layer 1 Variables
D_W1 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([784, 1024]))
D_B1 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([1024]))

# Layer 2 Variables
D_W2 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([1024, 512]))
D_B2 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([512]))

# Layer 3 Variables
D_W3 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([512, 256]))
D_B3 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([256]))

# Out Layer Variables
D_W4 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([256, 1]))
D_B4 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([1]))

# Store Variables in list
D_var_list = [D_W1, D_B1, D_W2, D_B2, D_W3, D_B3, D_W4, D_B4]

## Generator

# Input
Z = tf.placeholder(tf.float32, shape=(None, NOISE_SIZE))

# Layer 1 Variables
G_W1 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([100, 256]))
G_B1 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([256]))

# Layer 2 Variables
G_W2 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([256, 512]))
G_B2 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([512]))

# Layer 3 Variables
G_W3 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([512, 1024]))
G_B3 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([1024]))

# Out Layer Variables
G_W4 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([1024, 784]))
G_B4 = tf.Variable(xavier_init([784]))

# Store Variables in list
G_var_list = [G_W1, G_B1, G_W2, G_B2, G_W3, G_B3, G_W4, G_B4]

def discriminator(x):
    l1 = tf.nn.dropout(tf.nn.leaky_relu(tf.matmul(x,   D_W1) + D_B1, .2), .3)
    l2 = tf.nn.dropout(tf.nn.leaky_relu(tf.matmul(l1,  D_W2) + D_B2, .2), .3)
    l3 = tf.nn.dropout(tf.nn.leaky_relu(tf.matmul(l2,  D_W3) + D_B3, .2), .3)
    out = tf.matmul(l3, D_W4) + D_B4
    return out

def generator(z):
    l1 = tf.nn.leaky_relu(tf.matmul(z,  G_W1) + G_B1, .2)
    l2 = tf.nn.leaky_relu(tf.matmul(l1, G_W2) + G_B2, .2)
    l3 = tf.nn.leaky_relu(tf.matmul(l2, G_W3) + G_B3, .2)
    out = tf.nn.tanh(tf.matmul(l3, G_W4) + G_B4)
    return out
    
G_sample = generator(Z)
D_real = discriminator(X)
D_fake = discriminator(G_sample)

# Losses
D_loss_real = tf.reduce_mean(tf.nn.sigmoid_cross_entropy_with_logits(logits=D_real, labels=tf.ones_like(D_real)))
D_loss_fake = tf.reduce_mean(tf.nn.sigmoid_cross_entropy_with_logits(logits=D_fake, labels=tf.zeros_like(D_fake)))
D_loss = D_loss_real + D_loss_fake
G_loss = tf.reduce_mean(tf.nn.sigmoid_cross_entropy_with_logits(logits=D_fake, labels=tf.ones_like(D_fake)))

# Optimizers
D_opt = tf.train.AdamOptimizer(2e-4).minimize(D_loss, var_list=D_var_list)
G_opt = tf.train.AdamOptimizer(2e-4).minimize(G_loss, var_list=G_var_list)"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>## Discriminator

<p dir="auto">Train</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="# Iterate through epochs
for epoch in range(num_epochs):
    for n_batch, (batch,_) in enumerate(data_loader):
        
        # 1. Train Discriminator
        X_batch = images_to_vectors(batch.permute(0, 2, 3, 1).numpy())
        feed_dict = {X: X_batch, Z: noise(BATCH_SIZE, NOISE_SIZE)}
        _, d_error, d_pred_real, d_pred_fake = session.run(
            [D_opt, D_loss, D_real, D_fake], feed_dict=feed_dict
        )

        # 2. Train Generator
        feed_dict = {Z: noise(BATCH_SIZE, NOISE_SIZE)}
        _, g_error = session.run(
            [G_opt, G_loss], feed_dict=feed_dict
        )

        if n_batch % 100 == 0:
            display.clear_output(True)
            # Generate images from test noise
            test_images = session.run(
                G_sample, feed_dict={Z: test_noise}
            )
            test_images = vectors_to_images(test_images)
            # Log Images
            logger.log_images(test_images, num_test_samples, epoch, n_batch, num_batches, format='NHWC');
            # Log Status
            logger.display_status(
                epoch, num_epochs, n_batch, num_batches,
                d_error, g_error, d_pred_real, d_pred_fake
            )"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code># Iterate through epochs

<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-generative-adversarial-networks" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#generative-adversarial-networks"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Generative adversarial networks</h1>
<p dir="auto">The original purpose of Generative adversarial networks(GAN) is to generate new data. It classically generates new images, but is applicable to wide range of domains. It learns the training set distribution and can generate new images that have never been seen before. In contrast to e.g., autoregressive models or RNNs (generating one word at a time), GANs generate the whole output all at once.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="GAN is proposed in 2005, the paper is Ian J. Goodfellow, Jean Pouget-Abadie, Mehdi Mirza, Bing Xu, David Warde-Farley, Sherjil Ozair, Aaron Courville, Yoshua Bengio. &quot;Generative Adversarial Networks&quot;, arxiv:1406.2661."><pre lang="{seealso}" class="notranslate"><code>GAN is proposed in 2005, the paper is Ian J. Goodfellow, Jean Pouget-Abadie, Mehdi Mirza, Bing Xu, David Warde-Farley, Sherjil Ozair, Aaron Courville, Yoshua Bengio. "Generative Adversarial Networks", arxiv:1406.2661.
</code></pre></div>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-overview" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#overview"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Overview</h2>
<p dir="auto">The structures of GANs are roughly as follows. They have two essential part, discriminator and generator.
Discriminator learns to become better at distinguishing real from generated images, and generator learns to generate better images to fool the discriminator.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} GAN structure
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/GAN/structure.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/GAN/structure.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">Illustration of GAN structure
:::</p>
<p dir="auto">Then, one question appears: why are GANs Called Generative Models?</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>The generative part comes from the fact that the model "generates" new data,</li>
<li>Most of the time, generative models use an approximation to compute the usually intractable distribution; here, the discriminator part does that approximation,</li>
<li>So, it does learn p(x).</li>
</ul>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-training" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#training"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Training</h2>
<p dir="auto">To make the model converge, we need to find a proper objective for it.
For the GAN, it is $\min\limits_{G} \max\limits_{D} V(D, G) = \mathbb{E}<em>{x \thicksim p</em>{data}}[log D(x)] + \mathbb{E}_{z\thicksim p_z(z)}[log(1-D(G(z)))]$</p>
<h3 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-discriminator-gradient-for-update-gradient-ascent" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#discriminator-gradient-for-update-gradient-ascent"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Discriminator gradient for update (gradient ascent)</h3>
<p dir="auto">The aim of Discriminator is <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="dc25d166d646e65fedcd61a538b5a73a">$\bigtriangledown_{W_D} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n [log D(x^{(i)}) + log (1-D(G(z^{(i)})))]$</math-renderer>. We can split it into two parts.
First is <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="dc25d166d646e65fedcd61a538b5a73a">$D(x^{(i)})$</math-renderer>. If it predicts well in real images, the probability will be close to <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="dc25d166d646e65fedcd61a538b5a73a">$1$</math-renderer>.
Second is <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="dc25d166d646e65fedcd61a538b5a73a">$D(G(z^{(i)}))$</math-renderer>. This part use to predict the fake images which generdated from the generator, and if it predicts well, the probability will be close to <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="dc25d166d646e65fedcd61a538b5a73a">$0$</math-renderer>.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-generator-gradient-for-update-gradient-descent" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#generator-gradient-for-update-gradient-descent"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Generator gradient for update (gradient descent)</h3>
<p dir="auto">The aim of Generator is <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="dc25d166d646e65fedcd61a538b5a73a">$\bigtriangledown_{W_G} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n log(1-D(G(z^{(i)})))$</math-renderer>.
<math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="dc25d166d646e65fedcd61a538b5a73a">$D(G(z^{(i)}))$</math-renderer> is also used to predict fake images, but if it predicts badly on fake images, the probability will be close to 1, which is not same to discriminator.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-train-for-convergence" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#train-for-convergence"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Train for convergence</h3>
<p dir="auto">GAN converges when probabilities are close to 0.5, which means G can cheat D.
rom a mathematical point of view, it converges when Nash-equilibrium (Game Theory concept) is reached in the minmax (zero-sum) game.
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium" rel="nofollow">Nash-Equilibrium</a> in Game Theory is reached when the actions of one player won't change depending on the opponent's actions.</p>
<p dir="auto">But not each time GAN can converge, there are some training problems:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Oscillation between generator and discriminator loss,</li>
<li>Mode collapse (generator produces examples of a particular kind only),</li>
<li>Discriminator is too strong, such that the gradient for the generator vanishes and the generator can't keep up,</li>
<li>Discriminator is too weak, and the generator produces non-realistic images that fool it too easily (rare problem, though).</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">For the third problem, replacing <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="dc25d166d646e65fedcd61a538b5a73a">$\bigtriangledown_{W_G} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n log(1-D(G(z^{(i)})))$</math-renderer> with <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="dc25d166d646e65fedcd61a538b5a73a">$\bigtriangledown_{W_G} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n log(D(G(z^{(i)})))$</math-renderer> can be a good choice.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-loss" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#loss"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Loss</h3>
<p dir="auto">Discriminator:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Maximize prediction probability of classifying real as real and fake as fake,</li>
<li>Remember maximizing log likelihood is the same as minimizing negative log likelihood (i.e., minimizing cross-entropy).
Generator:</li>
<li>Minimize likelihood of the discriminator to make correct predictions (predict fake as fake; real as real), which can be achieved by maximizing the cross-entropy,</li>
<li>This doesn't work well in practice though because of gradient issues (zero gradient if the discriminator makes correct predictions, which is not what we want for the generator),</li>
<li>Better: flip labels and minimize cross entropy (force the discriminator to output high probability for fake if an image is real, and high probability for real if an image is fake).</li>
</ul>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-code" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#code"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Code</h3>
<p dir="auto">Here we implement a GAN model.</p>

from torch.utils.data import DataLoader
from torchvision import transforms, datasets

from utils import Logger

import tensorflow as tf
import tensorflow.compat.v1 as tf
tf.disable_v2_behavior() 

import numpy as np
from tensorflow.examples.tutorials.mnist import input_data

mnist=input_data.read_data_sets('./tf_data/VGAN/MNIST',one_hot=True)
DATA_FOLDER = './tf_data/VGAN/MNIST'
IMAGE_PIXELS = 28*28
NOISE_SIZE = 100
BATCH_SIZE = 100

def noise(n_rows, n_cols):
    return np.random.normal(size=(n_rows, n_cols))

def xavier_init(size):
    in_dim = size[0] if len(size) == 1 else size[1]
    stddev = 1. / np.sqrt(float(in_dim))
    return tf.random_uniform(shape=size, minval=-stddev, maxval=stddev)

def images_to_vectors(images):
    return images.reshape(images.shape[0], 784)

def vectors_to_images(vectors):
    return vectors.reshape(vectors.shape[0], 28, 28, 1)
