<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-recurrent-neural-networks" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#recurrent-neural-networks"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Recurrent Neural Networks</h1>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="The nervous system contains many circular paths, whose activity so regenerates the excitation of any participant neuron that reference to time past becomes indefinite, although it still implies that afferent activity has realized one of a certain class of configurations over time. Precise specification of these implications by means of recursive functions, and determination of those that can be embodied in the activity of nervous nets, completes the theory.

-- Warren McCulloch and Walter Pitts, 1943"><pre lang="{epigraph}" class="notranslate"><code>The nervous system contains many circular paths, whose activity so regenerates the excitation of any participant neuron that reference to time past becomes indefinite, although it still implies that afferent activity has realized one of a certain class of configurations over time. Precise specification of these implications by means of recursive functions, and determination of those that can be embodied in the activity of nervous nets, completes the theory.

-- Warren McCulloch and Walter Pitts, 1943
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">A recurrent neural network (RNN) is a type of artificial neural network that uses sequential data or time series data and it is mainly used for Natural Language Processing. Now let us see what it looks like.</p>
<p dir="auto">Sequential data is not <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_and_identically_distributed_random_variables" rel="nofollow">independent and identically distributed</a>.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} sequential data
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/sequential_data.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/sequential_data.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">sequential data
:::</p>
<p dir="auto">And the RNNs use recurrent edge to update.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} rnn1
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/rnn1.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/rnn1.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">RNN1
:::</p>
<p dir="auto">If unroll over a sequence <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="5b5dd8e491492afa3083d1d49799de26">$(x_0,x_1,x_2)$</math-renderer>.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} rnn2
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/rnn2.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/rnn2.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">RNN2
:::</p>
<p dir="auto">Then, the input (w0,w1,...,wt) sequence of words ( 1-hot encoded ) and the output (w1,w2,...,wt+1) shifted sequence of words ( 1-hot encoded ) have the following relation.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} rnn3
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/rnn3.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/rnn3.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">RNN3
:::</p>
<p dir="auto">The input projection is <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="5b5dd8e491492afa3083d1d49799de26">$x_t = Emb(\omega_t) = E\omega_t$</math-renderer>, the recurrent connection is <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="5b5dd8e491492afa3083d1d49799de26">$h_t = g(W^h h_t + x_t + b^h)$</math-renderer>, and the output projection should be <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="5b5dd8e491492afa3083d1d49799de26">$y = softmax(W^o h_t + b^o)$</math-renderer>.
The backpropagation of RNN is in this way:</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} rnn4
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/rnn4.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/rnn4.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">RNN4
:::</p>
<p dir="auto">Let's make the backpropagation process more clearly.</p>
<p dir="auto">First, we unfold a single-hidden layer RNN, and we can see the weight matrices <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="5b5dd8e491492afa3083d1d49799de26">$W_h$</math-renderer> in it.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} backpropagation
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/bp_rnn1.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/RNN/bp_rnn1.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">backpropagation for RNN
:::</p>
<p dir="auto">Through the image, we can get the output:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Net input: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="5b5dd8e491492afa3083d1d49799de26">$z_h^{} = W_hx x^{} + W_hh h^{} + b_h$</math-renderer>
</li>
<li>Activation: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="5b5dd8e491492afa3083d1d49799de26">$h^{} = \sigma (z_h^{})$</math-renderer>
</li>
<li>Output: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="5b5dd8e491492afa3083d1d49799de26">$z_y^ = W_yh h^{} + b_y$</math-renderer>, <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="5b5dd8e491492afa3083d1d49799de26">$y^{} = \sigma(z_y^{})$</math-renderer>
</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">After that, the loss is computed as the sum over all time steps: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="5b5dd8e491492afa3083d1d49799de26">$L = \sum_{t=1}^T L^{}$</math-renderer></p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="There are some key points:

- Similar as training very deep networks with tied parameters.
- Example between $x_0$ and $y_2$: Wh is used twice.
- Usually truncate the backprop after $T$ timesteps.
- Difficulties to train long-term dependencies."><pre lang="{note}" class="notranslate"><code>There are some key points:

- Similar as training very deep networks with tied parameters.
- Example between $x_0$ and $y_2$: Wh is used twice.
- Usually truncate the backprop after $T$ timesteps.
- Difficulties to train long-term dependencies.
</code></pre></div>
<h2 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-code" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#code"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Code</h2>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="# A text classifier implemented in TensorFlow to classify SMS spam messages.

# Code first downloads and processes the SMS Spam Collection dataset from the UCI Machine Learning Repository and then builds a basic Recurrent neural network (RNN) for text classification using TensorFlow.

# The code first cleans and preprocesses the text, then splits it into training and test sets, followed by tokenizing and padding the training set. Next, the code uses an embedding layer to convert the tokenized text into a vector representation, which is then fed into a recurrent neural network and finally classified using a Softmax loss function.

#The output of the # code is the accuracy of the classifier along with some statistics

# We implement an RNN in TensorFlow to predict spam/ham from texts

import os
import re
import io
import requests
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import tensorflow.compat.v1 as tf
from zipfile import ZipFile
from tensorflow.python.framework import ops
tf.disable_v2_behavior()
ops.reset_default_graph()

# Start a graph
sess = tf.Session()

# Set RNN parameters
epochs = 20
batch_size = 250
max_sequence_length =25 
rnn_size = 10
embedding_size = 50
min_word_frequency = 10
learning_rate = 0.0005
dropout_keep_prob = tf.placeholder(tf.float32,name='dropout_keep_prob')


# Download or open data
data_dir = 'temp'
data_file = 'text_data.txt'
if not os.path.exists(data_dir):
    os.makedirs(data_dir)

if not os.path.isfile(os.path.join(data_dir, data_file)):
    zip_url = 'http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/machine-learning-databases/00228/smsspamcollection.zip'
    r = requests.get(zip_url)
    z = ZipFile(io.BytesIO(r.content))
    file = z.read('SMSSpamCollection')
    # Format Data
    text_data = file.decode()
    text_data = text_data.encode('ascii', errors='ignore')
    text_data = text_data.decode().split('\n')

    # Save data to text file
    with open(os.path.join(data_dir, data_file), 'w') as file_conn:
        for text in text_data:
            file_conn.write(&quot;{}\n&quot;.format(text))
else:
    # Open data from text file
    text_data = []
    with open(os.path.join(data_dir, data_file), 'r') as file_conn:
        for row in file_conn:
            text_data.append(row)
    text_data = text_data[:-1]

text_data = [x.split('\t') for x in text_data if len(x) &gt;= 1]
[text_data_target, text_data_train] = [list(x) for x in zip(*text_data)]


# Create a text cleaning function
def clean_text(text_string):
    text_string = re.sub(r'([^\s\w]|_|[0-9])+', '', text_string)
    text_string = &quot; &quot;.join(text_string.split())
    text_string = text_string.lower()
    return text_string

# Clean texts
text_data_train = [clean_text(x) for x in text_data_train]
#print(text_data[:5])
print(text_data_train[:5])

# Tokenize and pad sequences
vocab_processor = tf.keras.preprocessing.text.Tokenizer()
vocab_processor.fit_on_texts(text_data_train)
text_processed = vocab_processor.texts_to_sequences(text_data_train)
max_document_length = max([len(x) for x in text_processed])
#pads the text data to ensure all sequences have the same length (max_sequence_length).
text_processed = tf.keras.preprocessing.sequence.pad_sequences(text_processed, maxlen=max_sequence_length, padding='post')
print(text_processed.shape)
# Shuffle and split data
text_processed = np.array(text_processed)
text_data_target = np.array([1 if x == 'ham' else 0 for x in text_data_target])
shuffled_ix = np.random.permutation(np.arange(len(text_data_target)))
x_shuffled = text_processed[shuffled_ix]
y_shuffled = text_data_target[shuffled_ix]

# Split train/test set
ix_cutoff = int(len(y_shuffled)*0.80)
x_train, x_test = x_shuffled[:ix_cutoff], x_shuffled[ix_cutoff:]
print(x_train)
y_train, y_test = y_shuffled[:ix_cutoff], y_shuffled[ix_cutoff:]
vocab_size = len(vocab_processor.word_counts)
print(&quot;Vocabulary Size: {:d}&quot;.format(vocab_size))
print(&quot;80-20 Train Test split: {:d} -- {:d}&quot;.format(len(y_train), len(y_test)))

# Create placeholders
x_data = tf.placeholder(tf.int32, [None, max_sequence_length])
y_output = tf.placeholder(tf.int32, [None])

# Create embedding
embedding_mat = tf.Variable(tf.random_uniform([vocab_size+1, embedding_size], -1.0, 1.0))
embedding_output = tf.nn.embedding_lookup(embedding_mat, x_data)

# Define the RNN cell
# tensorflow change &gt;= 1.0, rnn is put into tensorflow.contrib directory. Prior version not test.
cell = tf.nn.rnn_cell.BasicRNNCell(num_units=rnn_size)

output, state = tf.nn.dynamic_rnn(cell, embedding_output, dtype=tf.float32)
output = tf.nn.dropout(output, dropout_keep_prob)

# Get output of RNN sequence
output = tf.transpose(output, [1, 0, 2])
last = tf.gather(output, int(output.get_shape()[0]) - 1)

weight = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([rnn_size, 2], stddev=0.1))
bias = tf.Variable(tf.constant(0.1, shape=[2]))
logits_out = tf.matmul(last, weight) + bias


# Loss function
losses = tf.nn.sparse_softmax_cross_entropy_with_logits(logits=logits_out, labels=y_output)
loss = tf.reduce_mean(losses)
print(loss)
accuracy = tf.reduce_mean(tf.cast(tf.equal(tf.argmax(logits_out, 1), tf.cast(y_output, tf.int64)), tf.float32))
print(accuracy)
optimizer = tf.train.RMSPropOptimizer(learning_rate)
train_step = optimizer.minimize(loss)
init = tf.global_variables_initializer()
sess.run(init)

train_loss = []
test_loss = []
train_accuracy = []
test_accuracy = []
# Start training
for epoch in range(epochs):
    # Shuffle training data
    shuffled_ix = np.random.permutation(np.arange(len(x_train)))
    x_train = x_train[shuffled_ix]
    y_train = y_train[shuffled_ix]
    num_batches = int(len(x_train)/batch_size) + 1
    # TO DO CALCULATE GENERATIONS ExACTLY
    for i in range(num_batches):
        # Select train data
        min_ix = i * batch_size
        max_ix = np.min([len(x_train), ((i+1) * batch_size)])
        x_train_batch = x_train[min_ix:max_ix]
        y_train_batch = y_train[min_ix:max_ix]
        max_len = max([len(x) for x in x_train_batch])
        x_train_batch = np.array([np.pad(x, (0, max_len - len(x)), 'constant') for x in x_train_batch])
        # Run train step
        train_dict = {x_data: x_train_batch, y_output: y_train_batch, dropout_keep_prob:0.5}
        sess.run(train_step, feed_dict=train_dict)
    # Run loss and accuracy for training
    train_dict = {x_data: x_train, y_output: y_train, dropout_keep_prob:1.0}
    temp_train_loss, temp_train_acc = sess.run([loss, accuracy], feed_dict=train_dict)
    train_loss.append(temp_train_loss)
    train_accuracy.append(temp_train_acc)
    # Run Eval Step
    test_dict = {x_data: x_test, y_output: y_test, dropout_keep_prob:1.0}
    temp_test_loss, temp_test_acc = sess.run([loss, accuracy], feed_dict=test_dict)
    test_loss.append(temp_test_loss)
    test_accuracy.append(temp_test_acc)
    print('Epoch: {}, Test Loss: {:.2}, Test Acc: {:.2}'.format(epoch+1, temp_test_loss, temp_test_acc))
    
# Plot loss over time
epoch_seq = np.arange(1, epochs+1)
plt.plot(epoch_seq, train_loss, 'k--', label='Train Set')
plt.plot(epoch_seq, test_loss, 'r-', label='Test Set')
plt.title('Softmax Loss')
plt.xlabel('Epochs')
plt.ylabel('Softmax Loss')
plt.legend(loc='upper left')
plt.show()

# Plot accuracy over time
plt.plot(epoch_seq, train_accuracy, 'k--', label='Train Set')
plt.plot(epoch_seq, test_accuracy, 'r-', label='Test Set')
plt.title('Test Accuracy')
plt.xlabel('Epochs')
plt.ylabel('Accuracy')
plt.legend(loc='upper left')
plt.show()"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code># A text classifier implemented in TensorFlow to classify SMS spam messages.

# Code first downloads and processes the SMS Spam Collection dataset from the UCI Machine Learning Repository and then builds a basic Recurrent neural network (RNN) for text classification using TensorFlow.

# The code first cleans and preprocesses the text, then splits it into training and test sets, followed by tokenizing and padding the training set. Next, the code uses an embedding layer to convert the tokenized text into a vector representation, which is then fed into a recurrent neural network and finally classified using a Softmax loss function.

#The output of the # code is the accuracy of the classifier along with some statistics

# We implement an RNN in TensorFlow to predict spam/ham from texts

import os
import re
import io
import requests
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import tensorflow.compat.v1 as tf
from zipfile import ZipFile
from tensorflow.python.framework import ops
tf.disable_v2_behavior()
ops.reset_default_graph()

# Start a graph
sess = tf.Session()

# Set RNN parameters
epochs = 20
batch_size = 250
max_sequence_length =25 
rnn_size = 10
embedding_size = 50
min_word_frequency = 10
learning_rate = 0.0005
dropout_keep_prob = tf.placeholder(tf.float32,name='dropout_keep_prob')


# Download or open data
data_dir = 'temp'
data_file = 'text_data.txt'
if not os.path.exists(data_dir):
    os.makedirs(data_dir)

if not os.path.isfile(os.path.join(data_dir, data_file)):
    zip_url = 'http://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/machine-learning-databases/00228/smsspamcollection.zip'
    r = requests.get(zip_url)
    z = ZipFile(io.BytesIO(r.content))
    file = z.read('SMSSpamCollection')
    # Format Data
    text_data = file.decode()
    text_data = text_data.encode('ascii', errors='ignore')
    text_data = text_data.decode().split('\n')

    # Save data to text file
    with open(os.path.join(data_dir, data_file), 'w') as file_conn:
        for text in text_data:
            file_conn.write("{}\n".format(text))
else:
    # Open data from text file
    text_data = []
    with open(os.path.join(data_dir, data_file), 'r') as file_conn:
        for row in file_conn:
            text_data.append(row)
    text_data = text_data[:-1]

text_data = [x.split('\t') for x in text_data if len(x) &gt;= 1]
[text_data_target, text_data_train] = [list(x) for x in zip(*text_data)]


# Create a text cleaning function
def clean_text(text_string):
    text_string = re.sub(r'([^\s\w]|_|[0-9])+', '', text_string)
    text_string = " ".join(text_string.split())
    text_string = text_string.lower()
    return text_string

# Clean texts
text_data_train = [clean_text(x) for x in text_data_train]
#print(text_data[:5])
print(text_data_train[:5])

# Tokenize and pad sequences
vocab_processor = tf.keras.preprocessing.text.Tokenizer()
vocab_processor.fit_on_texts(text_data_train)
text_processed = vocab_processor.texts_to_sequences(text_data_train)
max_document_length = max([len(x) for x in text_processed])
#pads the text data to ensure all sequences have the same length (max_sequence_length).
text_processed = tf.keras.preprocessing.sequence.pad_sequences(text_processed, maxlen=max_sequence_length, padding='post')
print(text_processed.shape)
# Shuffle and split data
text_processed = np.array(text_processed)
text_data_target = np.array([1 if x == 'ham' else 0 for x in text_data_target])
shuffled_ix = np.random.permutation(np.arange(len(text_data_target)))
x_shuffled = text_processed[shuffled_ix]
y_shuffled = text_data_target[shuffled_ix]

# Split train/test set
ix_cutoff = int(len(y_shuffled)*0.80)
x_train, x_test = x_shuffled[:ix_cutoff], x_shuffled[ix_cutoff:]
print(x_train)
y_train, y_test = y_shuffled[:ix_cutoff], y_shuffled[ix_cutoff:]
vocab_size = len(vocab_processor.word_counts)
print("Vocabulary Size: {:d}".format(vocab_size))
print("80-20 Train Test split: {:d} -- {:d}".format(len(y_train), len(y_test)))

# Create placeholders
x_data = tf.placeholder(tf.int32, [None, max_sequence_length])
y_output = tf.placeholder(tf.int32, [None])

# Create embedding
embedding_mat = tf.Variable(tf.random_uniform([vocab_size+1, embedding_size], -1.0, 1.0))
embedding_output = tf.nn.embedding_lookup(embedding_mat, x_data)

# Define the RNN cell
# tensorflow change &gt;= 1.0, rnn is put into tensorflow.contrib directory. Prior version not test.
cell = tf.nn.rnn_cell.BasicRNNCell(num_units=rnn_size)

output, state = tf.nn.dynamic_rnn(cell, embedding_output, dtype=tf.float32)
output = tf.nn.dropout(output, dropout_keep_prob)

# Get output of RNN sequence
output = tf.transpose(output, [1, 0, 2])
last = tf.gather(output, int(output.get_shape()[0]) - 1)

weight = tf.Variable(tf.truncated_normal([rnn_size, 2], stddev=0.1))
bias = tf.Variable(tf.constant(0.1, shape=[2]))
logits_out = tf.matmul(last, weight) + bias


# Loss function
losses = tf.nn.sparse_softmax_cross_entropy_with_logits(logits=logits_out, labels=y_output)
loss = tf.reduce_mean(losses)
print(loss)
accuracy = tf.reduce_mean(tf.cast(tf.equal(tf.argmax(logits_out, 1), tf.cast(y_output, tf.int64)), tf.float32))
print(accuracy)
optimizer = tf.train.RMSPropOptimizer(learning_rate)
train_step = optimizer.minimize(loss)
init = tf.global_variables_initializer()
sess.run(init)

train_loss = []
test_loss = []
train_accuracy = []
test_accuracy = []
# Start training
for epoch in range(epochs):
    # Shuffle training data
    shuffled_ix = np.random.permutation(np.arange(len(x_train)))
    x_train = x_train[shuffled_ix]
    y_train = y_train[shuffled_ix]
    num_batches = int(len(x_train)/batch_size) + 1
    # TO DO CALCULATE GENERATIONS ExACTLY
    for i in range(num_batches):
        # Select train data
        min_ix = i * batch_size
        max_ix = np.min([len(x_train), ((i+1) * batch_size)])
        x_train_batch = x_train[min_ix:max_ix]
        y_train_batch = y_train[min_ix:max_ix]
        max_len = max([len(x) for x in x_train_batch])
        x_train_batch = np.array([np.pad(x, (0, max_len - len(x)), 'constant') for x in x_train_batch])
        # Run train step
        train_dict = {x_data: x_train_batch, y_output: y_train_batch, dropout_keep_prob:0.5}
        sess.run(train_step, feed_dict=train_dict)
    # Run loss and accuracy for training
    train_dict = {x_data: x_train, y_output: y_train, dropout_keep_prob:1.0}
    temp_train_loss, temp_train_acc = sess.run([loss, accuracy], feed_dict=train_dict)
    train_loss.append(temp_train_loss)
    train_accuracy.append(temp_train_acc)
    # Run Eval Step
    test_dict = {x_data: x_test, y_output: y_test, dropout_keep_prob:1.0}
    temp_test_loss, temp_test_acc = sess.run([loss, accuracy], feed_dict=test_dict)
    test_loss.append(temp_test_loss)
    test_accuracy.append(temp_test_acc)
    print('Epoch: {}, Test Loss: {:.2}, Test Acc: {:.2}'.format(epoch+1, temp_test_loss, temp_test_acc))
    
# Plot loss over time
epoch_seq = np.arange(1, epochs+1)
plt.plot(epoch_seq, train_loss, 'k--', label='Train Set')
plt.plot(epoch_seq, test_loss, 'r-', label='Test Set')
plt.title('Softmax Loss')
plt.xlabel('Epochs')
plt.ylabel('Softmax Loss')
plt.legend(loc='upper left')
plt.show()

# Plot accuracy over time
plt.plot(epoch_seq, train_accuracy, 'k--', label='Train Set')
plt.plot(epoch_seq, test_accuracy, 'r-', label='Test Set')
plt.title('Test Accuracy')
plt.xlabel('Epochs')
plt.ylabel('Accuracy')
plt.legend(loc='upper left')
plt.show()

<h1 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-time-series" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#time-series"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Time series</h1>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-overiew" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#overiew"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Overiew</h2>
<p dir="auto">Time series forecasting is a broad field with a long history and forcasting is perhaps the most common application in the real world. Businesses forecast product demand, governments forecast economic and population growth, meteorologists forecast the weather. The understanding of things to come is a pressing need across science, government, and industry (not to mention our personal lives!), and practitioners in these fields are increasingly applying machine learning to address this need.</p>
<p dir="auto">After finishing this course, you'll know how to:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>engineer features to model the major time series components (trends, seasons, and cycles),</li>
<li>visualize time series with many kinds of time series plots,</li>
<li>create forecasting hybrids that combine the strengths of complementary models, and</li>
<li>adapt machine learning methods to a variety of forecasting tasks.</li>
</ul>
<h2 dir="auto"><a id="user-content-what-is-a-time-series" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#what-is-a-time-series"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>What is a Time Series?</h2>
<p dir="auto">The basic object of forecasting is the time series, which is a set of observations recorded over time. In forecasting applications, the observations are typically recorded with a regular frequency, like daily or monthly.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="kaggle kernels output ryanholbrook/linear-regression-with-time-series -p /path/to/dest
https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/store-sales-time-series-forecasting"><pre lang="{seealso}" class="notranslate"><code>kaggle kernels output ryanholbrook/linear-regression-with-time-series -p /path/to/dest
https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/store-sales-time-series-forecasting
</code></pre></div>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv(
    &quot;../assets/data/book_sales.csv&quot;,
    index_col='Date',
    parse_dates=['Date'],

df.head()"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>import pandas as pd

    index_col='Date',
    parse_dates=['Date'],

<p dir="auto">This series records the number of hardcover book sales at a retail store over 30 days. Notice that we have a single column of observations <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$Hardcover$</math-renderer> with a time index <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$Date$</math-renderer>.</p>
<h2 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-linear-regression-with-time-series" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#linear-regression-with-time-series"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Linear Regression with Time Series</h2>
<p dir="auto">For the first part of this course, we'll use the linear regression algorithm to construct forecasting models. Linear regression is widely used in practice and adapts naturally to even complex forecasting tasks.</p>
<p dir="auto">The linear regression algorithm learns how to make a weighted sum from its input features. For two features, we would have:</p>
<p dir="auto"><math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$target = weight_1 * feature_1 + weight_2 * feature_2 + bias$</math-renderer></p>
<p dir="auto">During training, the regression algorithm learns values for the parameters <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$weight_1$</math-renderer>, <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$weight_2$</math-renderer>, and <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$bias$</math-renderer> that best fit the <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$target$</math-renderer>. (This algorithm is often called ordinary least squares since it chooses values that minimize the squared error between the target and the predictions.) The weights are also called regression coefficients and the bias is also called the intercept because it tells you where the graph of this function crosses the y-axis.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-time-step-features" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#time-step-features"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Time-step features</h3>
<p dir="auto">There are two kinds of features unique to time series: time-step features and lag features.</p>
<p dir="auto">Time-step features are features we can derive directly from the time index. The most basic time-step feature is the time dummy, which counts off time steps in the series from beginning to end.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import numpy as np
df['Time'] = np.arange(len(df.index))
df.head()"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>import numpy as np
df['Time'] = np.arange(len(df.index))
df.head()
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">Linear regression with the time dummy produces the model:</p>
<p dir="auto"><math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$target = weight * time + bias$</math-renderer></p>
<p dir="auto">The time dummy then lets us fit curves to time series in a time plot, where Time forms the x-axis.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns
plt.style.use(&quot;seaborn-whitegrid&quot;)
plt.rc(
    &quot;figure&quot;,
    autolayout=True,
    figsize=(11, 4),
    titlesize=18,
    titleweight='bold',
)
plt.rc(
    &quot;axes&quot;,
    labelweight=&quot;bold&quot;,
    labelsize=&quot;large&quot;,
    titleweight=&quot;bold&quot;,
    titlesize=16,
    titlepad=10,

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot('Time', 'Hardcover', data=df, color='0.75')

ax.set_title('Time Plot of Hardcover Sales');"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.style.use("seaborn-whitegrid")
plt.rc(
    "figure",
    autolayout=True,
    figsize=(11, 4),
    titlesize=18,
    titleweight='bold',
)
plt.rc(
    "axes",

    titleweight="bold",

<p dir="auto">Time-step features let you model time dependence. A series is time dependent if its values can be predicted from the time they occured. In the Hardcover Sales series, we can predict that sales later in the month are generally higher than sales earlier in the month.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-lag-features" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#lag-features"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Lag features</h3>
<p dir="auto">To make a lag feature we shift the observations of the target series so that they appear to have occured later in time. Here we've created a 1-step lag feature, though shifting by multiple steps is possible too.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="df['Lag_1'] = df['Hardcover'].shift(1)
df = df.reindex(columns=['Hardcover', 'Lag_1'])
df.head()"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>df['Lag_1'] = df['Hardcover'].shift(1)
df = df.reindex(columns=['Hardcover', 'Lag_1'])
df.head()
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">Linear regression with a lag feature produces the model: <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$target = weight * lag + bias$</math-renderer>. So lag features let us fit curves to lag plots where each observation in a series is plotted against the previous observation.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax = sns.regplot(x='Lag_1', y='Hardcover', data=df, ci=None, scatter_kws=dict(color='0.25'))
ax.set_aspect('equal')
ax.set_title('Lag Plot of Hardcover Sales');"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax = sns.regplot(x='Lag_1', y='Hardcover', data=df, ci=None, scatter_kws=dict(color='0.25'))
ax.set_aspect('equal')
ax.set_title('Lag Plot of Hardcover Sales');
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">You can see from the lag plot that sales on one day <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$(Hardcover)$</math-renderer> are correlated with sales from the previous day <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$(Lag_1)$</math-renderer>. When you see a relationship like this, you know a lag feature will be useful.</p>
<p dir="auto">More generally, lag features let you model serial dependence. A time series has serial dependence when an observation can be predicted from previous observations. In Hardcover Sales, we can predict that high sales on one day usually mean high sales the next day.</p>
<p dir="auto">Adapting machine learning algorithms to time series problems is largely about feature engineering with the time index and lags. For most of the course, we use linear regression for its simplicity, but these features will be useful whichever algorithm you choose for your forecasting task.</p>
<h2 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-example---tunnel-traffic" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#example---tunnel-traffic"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Example - Tunnel Traffic</h2>
<p dir="auto">Tunnel Traffic is a time series describing the number of vehicles traveling through the Baregg Tunnel in Switzerland each day from November 2003 to November 2005. In this example, we'll get some practice applying linear regression to time-step features and lag features.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from pathlib import Path
from warnings import simplefilter

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

simplefilter(&quot;ignore&quot;)  # ignore warnings to clean up output cells

# Set Matplotlib defaults
plt.style.use(&quot;seaborn-whitegrid&quot;)
plt.rc(&quot;figure&quot;, autolayout=True, figsize=(11, 4))
plt.rc(
    &quot;axes&quot;,
    labelweight=&quot;bold&quot;,
    labelsize=&quot;large&quot;,
    titleweight=&quot;bold&quot;,
    titlesize=14,
    titlepad=10,
)
plot_params = dict(
    color=&quot;0.75&quot;,
    style=&quot;.-&quot;,
    markeredgecolor=&quot;0.25&quot;,
    markerfacecolor=&quot;0.25&quot;,
    legend=False,
)
%config InlineBackend.figure_format = 'retina'


# Load Tunnel Traffic dataset
data_dir = Path(&quot;../assets/data&quot;)
tunnel = pd.read_csv(data_dir / &quot;tunnel.csv&quot;, parse_dates=[&quot;Day&quot;])

# Create a time series in Pandas by setting the index to a date
# column. We parsed &quot;Day&quot; as a date type by using `parse_dates` when
# loading the data.
tunnel = tunnel.set_index(&quot;Day&quot;)

# By default, Pandas creates a `DatetimeIndex` with dtype `Timestamp`
# (equivalent to `np.datetime64`, representing a time series as a
# sequence of measurements taken at single moments. A `PeriodIndex`,
# on the other hand, represents a time series as a sequence of
# quantities accumulated over periods of time. Periods are often
# easier to work with, so that's what we'll use in this course.
tunnel = tunnel.to_period()

tunnel.head()"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>from pathlib import Path

plot_params = dict(
    color="0.75",
    style=".-",
    markeredgecolor="0.25",
    markerfacecolor="0.25",
    legend=False,
)
%config InlineBackend.figure_format = 'retina'


# Load Tunnel Traffic dataset
data_dir = Path("../assets/data")
tunnel = pd.read_csv(data_dir / "tunnel.csv", parse_dates=["Day"])

# Create a time series in Pandas by setting the index to a date
# column. We parsed "Day" as a date type by using `parse_dates` when
# loading the data.
tunnel = tunnel.set_index("Day")

# By default, Pandas creates a `DatetimeIndex` with dtype `Timestamp`
# (equivalent to `np.datetime64`, representing a time series as a
# sequence of measurements taken at single moments. A `PeriodIndex`,
# on the other hand, represents a time series as a sequence of
# quantities accumulated over periods of time. Periods are often
# easier to work with, so that's what we'll use in this course.
tunnel = tunnel.to_period()

tunnel.head()
</code></pre></div>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-time-step-feature" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#time-step-feature"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Time-step feature</h3>
<p dir="auto">Provided the time series doesn't have any missing dates, we can create a time dummy by counting out the length of the series.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="df = tunnel.copy()

df['Time'] = np.arange(len(tunnel.index))

df.head()"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>df = tunnel.copy()

df['Time'] = np.arange(len(tunnel.index))

df.head()
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">The procedure for fitting a linear regression model follows the standard steps for scikit-learn.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

# Training data
X = df.loc[:, ['Time']]  # features
y = df.loc[:, 'NumVehicles']  # target

# Train the model
model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X, y)

# Store the fitted values as a time series with the same time index as
# the training data
y_pred = pd.Series(model.predict(X), index=X.index)"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

# Training data
X = df.loc[:, ['Time']]  # features
y = df.loc[:, 'NumVehicles']  # target

# Train the model
model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X, y)

# Store the fitted values as a time series with the same time index as
# the training data
y_pred = pd.Series(model.predict(X), index=X.index)
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">The model actually created is (approximately): <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$Vehicles = 22.5 * Time + 98176$</math-renderer>. Plotting the fitted values over time shows us how fitting linear regression to the time dummy creates the trend line defined by this equation.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="ax = y.plot(**plot_params)
ax = y_pred.plot(ax=ax, linewidth=3)
ax.set_title('Time Plot of Tunnel Traffic');"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>ax = y.plot(**plot_params)
ax = y_pred.plot(ax=ax, linewidth=3)
ax.set_title('Time Plot of Tunnel Traffic');
</code></pre></div>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-lag-feature" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#lag-feature"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Lag feature</h3>
<p dir="auto">Pandas provides us a simple method to lag a series, the <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$shift$</math-renderer> method.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="df['Lag_1'] = df['NumVehicles'].shift(1)
df.head()"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>df['Lag_1'] = df['NumVehicles'].shift(1)
df.head()
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">When creating lag features, we need to decide what to do with the missing values produced. Filling them in is one option, maybe with 0.0 or "backfilling" with the first known value. Instead, we'll just drop the missing values, making sure to also drop values in the target from corresponding dates.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

X = df.loc[:, ['Lag_1']]
X.dropna(inplace=True)  # drop missing values in the feature set
y = df.loc[:, 'NumVehicles']  # create the target
y, X = y.align(X, join='inner')  # drop corresponding values in target

model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X, y)

y_pred = pd.Series(model.predict(X), index=X.index)"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

X = df.loc[:, ['Lag_1']]
X.dropna(inplace=True)  # drop missing values in the feature set
y = df.loc[:, 'NumVehicles']  # create the target
y, X = y.align(X, join='inner')  # drop corresponding values in target

model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X, y)

y_pred = pd.Series(model.predict(X), index=X.index)
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">The lag plot shows us how well we were able to fit the relationship between the number of vehicles one day and the number the previous day.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(X['Lag_1'], y, '.', color='0.25')
ax.plot(X['Lag_1'], y_pred)
ax.set_aspect('equal')
ax.set_ylabel('NumVehicles')
ax.set_xlabel('Lag_1')
ax.set_title('Lag Plot of Tunnel Traffic');"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(X['Lag_1'], y, '.', color='0.25')
ax.plot(X['Lag_1'], y_pred)
ax.set_aspect('equal')
ax.set_ylabel('NumVehicles')
ax.set_xlabel('Lag_1')
ax.set_title('Lag Plot of Tunnel Traffic');
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">What does this prediction from a lag feature mean about how well we can predict the series across time? The following time plot shows us how our forecasts now respond to the behavior of the series in the recent past.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="ax = y.plot(**plot_params)
ax = y_pred.plot()"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>ax = y.plot(**plot_params)
ax = y_pred.plot()
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">The best time series models will usually include some combination of time-step features and lag features. Over the next few lessons, we'll learn how to engineer features modeling the most common patterns in time series using the features from this lesson as a starting point.</p>
<h2 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-forecasting-with-deep-learning" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#forecasting-with-deep-learning"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Forecasting With Deep Learning</h2>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-defining-the-forecasting-task" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#defining-the-forecasting-task"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Defining the Forecasting Task</h3>
<p dir="auto">There are two things to establish before designing a forecasting model:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>what information is available at the time a forecast is made (features),</li>
<li>the time period during which you require forecasted values (target).</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">The forecast origin is time at which you are making a forecast. Practically, you might consider the forecast origin to be the last time for which you have training data for the time being predicted. Everything up to he origin can be used to create features.</p>
<p dir="auto">The forecast horizon is the time for which you are making a forecast. We often describe a forecast by the number of time steps in its horizon: a "1-step" forecast or "5-step" forecast, say. The forecast horizon describes the target.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} 01_def
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/time-series/01_def.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/time-series/01_def.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">A three-step forecast horizon with a two-step lead time, using four lag features. The figure represents what would be a single row of training data -- data for a single prediction, in other words.
:::</p>
<p dir="auto">The time between the origin and the horizon is the lead time (or sometimes latency) of the forecast. A forecast's lead time is described by the number of steps from origin to horizon: a "1-step ahead" or "3-step ahead" forecast, say. In practice, it may be necessary for a forecast to begin multiple steps ahead of the origin because of delays in data acquisition or processing.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-preparing-data-for-forecasting" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#preparing-data-for-forecasting"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Preparing Data for Forecasting</h3>
<p dir="auto">In order to forecast time series with ML algorithms, we need to transform the series into a dataframe we can use with those algorithms. (Unless, of course, you are only using deterministic features like trend and seasonality.)</p>
<p dir="auto">We saw the first half of this process in Lesson 4 when we created a feature set out of lags. The second half is preparing the target. How we do this depends on the forecasting task.</p>
<p dir="auto">Each row in a dataframe represents a single forecast. The time index of the row is the first time in the forecast horizon, but we arrange values for the entire horizon in the same row. For multistep forecasts, this means we are requiring a model to produce multiple outputs, one for each step.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

N = 20
ts = pd.Series(
    np.arange(N),
    index=pd.period_range(start='2010', freq='A', periods=N, name='Year'),
    dtype=pd.Int8Dtype,
)

# Lag features
X = pd.DataFrame({
    'y_lag_2': ts.shift(2),
    'y_lag_3': ts.shift(3),
    'y_lag_4': ts.shift(4),
    'y_lag_5': ts.shift(5),
    'y_lag_6': ts.shift(6),    
})

# Multistep targets
y = pd.DataFrame({
    'y_step_3': ts.shift(-2),
    'y_step_2': ts.shift(-1),
    'y_step_1': ts,
})

data = pd.concat({'Targets': y, 'Features': X}, axis=1)

data.head(10).style.set_properties(['Targets'], **{'background-color': 'LavenderBlush'}) \
                   .set_properties(['Features'], **{'background-color': 'Lavender'})"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

N = 20
ts = pd.Series(
    np.arange(N),
    index=pd.period_range(start='2010', freq='A', periods=N, name='Year'),
    dtype=pd.Int8Dtype,
)

# Lag features
X = pd.DataFrame({
    'y_lag_2': ts.shift(2),
    'y_lag_3': ts.shift(3),
    'y_lag_4': ts.shift(4),
    'y_lag_5': ts.shift(5),
    'y_lag_6': ts.shift(6),    
})

# Multistep targets
y = pd.DataFrame({
    'y_step_3': ts.shift(-2),
    'y_step_2': ts.shift(-1),
    'y_step_1': ts,
})

data = pd.concat({'Targets': y, 'Features': X}, axis=1)

data.head(10).style.set_properties(['Targets'], **{'background-color': 'LavenderBlush'}) \
                   .set_properties(['Features'], **{'background-color': 'Lavender'})
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">The above illustrates how a dataset would be prepared similar to the Defining a Forecast figure: a three-step forecasting task with a two-step lead time using five lag features. The original time series is y_step_1. The missing values we could either fill-in or drop.</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-multistep-forecasting-strategies" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#multistep-forecasting-strategies"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Multistep Forecasting Strategies</h3>
<p dir="auto">There are a number of strategies for producing the multiple target steps required for a forecast. We'll outline four common strategies, each with strengths and weaknesses.</p>
<h4 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-multioutput-model" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#multioutput-model"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Multioutput model</h4>
<p dir="auto">Use a model that produces multiple outputs naturally. Linear regression and neural networks can both produce multiple outputs. This strategy is simple and efficient, but not possible for every algorithm you might want to use. XGBoost can't do this, for instance.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} 02_multioutput
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/time-series/02_multioutput.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/time-series/02_multioutput.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">Multioutput Model
:::</p>
<h4 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-direct-strategy" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#direct-strategy"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Direct strategy</h4>
<p dir="auto">Train a separate model for each step in the horizon: one model forecasts 1-step ahead, another 2-steps ahead, and so on. Forecasting 1-step ahead is a different problem than 2-steps ahead (and so on), so it can help to have a different model make forecasts for each step. The downside is that training lots of models can be computationally expensive.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} 03_direct
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/time-series/03_direct.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/time-series/03_direct.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">Direct Strategy
:::</p>
<h4 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-recursive-strategy" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#recursive-strategy"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Recursive strategy</h4>
<p dir="auto">Train a single one-step model and use its forecasts to update the lag features for the next step. With the recursive method, we feed a model's 1-step forecast back in to that same model to use as a lag feature for the next forecasting step. We only need to train one model, but since errors will propagate from step to step, forecasts can be inaccurate for long horizons.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} 04_recursive
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/time-series/04_recursive.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/time-series/04_recursive.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">Recursive Strategy
:::</p>
<h4 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-dirrec-strategy" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#dirrec-strategy"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>DirRec strategy</h4>
<p dir="auto">A combination of the direct and recursive strategies: train a model for each step and use forecasts from previous steps as new lag features. Step by step, each model gets an additional lag input. Since each model always has an up-to-date set of lag features, the DirRec strategy can capture serial dependence better than Direct, but it can also suffer from error propagation like Recursive.</p>
<p dir="auto">:::{figure-md} 05_dirrec
<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="/open-academy/machine-learning/blob/main/images/deep-learning/time-series/05_dirrec.png"><img src="/open-academy/machine-learning/raw/main/images/deep-learning/time-series/05_dirrec.png" width="90%" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p>
<p dir="auto">DirRec Strategy
:::</p>
<h3 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-example---flu-trends" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#example---flu-trends"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Example - Flu Trends</h3>
<p dir="auto">In this example we'll apply the MultiOutput and Direct strategies to the Flu Trends data from Lesson 4, this time making true forecasts for multiple weeks beyond the training period.</p>
<p dir="auto">We'll define our forecasting task to have an 8-week horizon with a 1-week lead time. In other words, we'll be forecasting eight weeks of flu cases starting with the following week.</p>
<p dir="auto">The hidden cell sets up the example and defines a helper function <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$plot_multistep$</math-renderer>.</p>

simplefilter("ignore")

# Set Matplotlib defaults
plt.style.use("seaborn-whitegrid")
plt.rc("figure", autolayout=True, figsize=(11, 4))
plt.rc(
    "axes",
    labelweight="bold",
    labelsize="large",
    titleweight="bold",
    titlesize=16,
    titlepad=10,
)
plot_params = dict(
    color="0.75",
    style=".-",
    markeredgecolor="0.25",
    markerfacecolor="0.25",
)
%config InlineBackend.figure_format = 'retina'


def plot_multistep(y, every=1, ax=None, palette_kwargs=None):
    palette_kwargs_ = dict(palette='husl', n_colors=16, desat=None)
    if palette_kwargs is not None:
        palette_kwargs_.update(palette_kwargs)

data_dir = Path("../assets/data")

</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">First we'll prepare our target series (weekly office visits for the flu) for multistep forecasting. Once this is done, training and prediction will be very straightfoward.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="def make_lags(ts, lags, lead_time=1):
    return pd.concat(
        {
            f'y_lag_{i}': ts.shift(i)
            for i in range(lead_time, lags + lead_time)
        },
        axis=1)


# Four weeks of lag features
y = flu_trends.FluVisits.copy()
X = make_lags(y, lags=4).fillna(0.0)


def make_multistep_target(ts, steps):
    return pd.concat(
        {f'y_step_{i + 1}': ts.shift(-i)
         for i in range(steps)},
        axis=1)


# Eight-week forecast
y = make_multistep_target(y, steps=8).dropna()

# Shifting has created indexes that don't match. Only keep times for
# which we have both targets and features.
y, X = y.align(X, join='inner', axis=0)"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>def make_lags(ts, lags, lead_time=1):
    return pd.concat(
        {
            f'y_lag_{i}': ts.shift(i)
            for i in range(lead_time, lags + lead_time)
        },
        axis=1)


# Four weeks of lag features
y = flu_trends.FluVisits.copy()
X = make_lags(y, lags=4).fillna(0.0)


def make_multistep_target(ts, steps):
    return pd.concat(
        {f'y_step_{i + 1}': ts.shift(-i)
         for i in range(steps)},
        axis=1)


# Eight-week forecast
y = make_multistep_target(y, steps=8).dropna()

# Shifting has created indexes that don't match. Only keep times for
# which we have both targets and features.
y, X = y.align(X, join='inner', axis=0)
</code></pre></div>
<h4 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-multioutput-model-1" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#multioutput-model-1"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Multioutput model</h4>
<p dir="auto">We'll use linear regression as a MultiOutput strategy. Once we have our data prepared for multiple outputs, training and prediction is the same as always.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="# Create splits
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.25, shuffle=False)

model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

y_fit = pd.DataFrame(model.predict(X_train), index=X_train.index, columns=y.columns)
y_pred = pd.DataFrame(model.predict(X_test), index=X_test.index, columns=y.columns)"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code># Create splits
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.25, shuffle=False)

model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

y_fit = pd.DataFrame(model.predict(X_train), index=X_train.index, columns=y.columns)
y_pred = pd.DataFrame(model.predict(X_test), index=X_test.index, columns=y.columns)
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">Remember that a multistep model will produce a complete forecast for each instance used as input. There are 269 weeks in the training set and 90 weeks in the test set, and we now have an 8-step forecast for each of these weeks.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="train_rmse = mean_squared_error(y_train, y_fit, squared=False)
test_rmse = mean_squared_error(y_test, y_pred, squared=False)
print((f&quot;Train RMSE: {train_rmse:.2f}\n&quot; f&quot;Test RMSE: {test_rmse:.2f}&quot;))

palette = dict(palette='husl', n_colors=64)
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(2, 1, figsize=(11, 6))
ax1 = flu_trends.FluVisits[y_fit.index].plot(**plot_params, ax=ax1)
ax1 = plot_multistep(y_fit, ax=ax1, palette_kwargs=palette)

<h4 dir="auto">
<a id="user-content-direct-strategy-1" class="anchor" aria-hidden="true" href="#direct-strategy-1"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a>Direct strategy</h4>
<p dir="auto">XGBoost can't produce multiple outputs for regression tasks. But by applying the Direct reduction strategy, we can still use it to produce multi-step forecasts. This is as easy as wrapping it with scikit-learn's <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$MultiOutputRegressor$</math-renderer>.</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="from sklearn.multioutput import MultiOutputRegressor

model = MultiOutputRegressor(XGBRegressor())
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

y_fit = pd.DataFrame(model.predict(X_train), index=X_train.index, columns=y.columns)
y_pred = pd.DataFrame(model.predict(X_test), index=X_test.index, columns=y.columns)"><pre lang="{code-cell}" class="notranslate"><code>from sklearn.multioutput import MultiOutputRegressor

model = MultiOutputRegressor(XGBRegressor())
model.fit(X_train, y_train)

y_fit = pd.DataFrame(model.predict(X_train), index=X_train.index, columns=y.columns)
y_pred = pd.DataFrame(model.predict(X_test), index=X_test.index, columns=y.columns)
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">XGBoost here is clearly overfitting on the training set. But on the test set it seems it was able to capture some of the dynamics of the flu season better than the linear regression model. It would likely do even better with some hyperparameter tuning.</p>

<p dir="auto">To use the DirRec strategy, you would only need to replace <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$MultiOutputRegressor$</math-renderer> with another scikit-learn wrapper, <math-renderer class="js-inline-math" style="display: inline" data-static-url="https://github.githubassets.com/static" data-run-id="38af090fe86339f1dc9ea2a5b61cc3a3">$RegressorChain$</math-renderer>. The Recursive strategy we would need to code ourselves.</p>
